sub_subject.name: Journalism & Nonfiction Writing
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Journalism & Nonfiction Writing (Language Arts & Humanities)

objectives.objective_text: Identify the title of a news story.
Identify a fact (It is raining) vs. a feeling (I hate rain).
Name a story that is true.
Identify 'loaded' words that show feelings.
Identify the most important part of a story.
Name the 'Who' and 'What' of an event.
Identify unkind words.
Name gossip as telling secrets that hurt people.
Identify a lie vs. the truth.
Name honesty as a good trait.
Identify the 'Angle' of the story.
Identify the most interesting quote.
Identify a problem in the school or town.
Recall that a title tells us what the story is about.
Observe bold letters at the top of a page.
Recall that we should tell the truth about what happened.
Observe that different people see different things.
Recall that news tells us what is happening now.
Recall that words can hurt like sticks and stones.
Observe that we should speak helpful words.
Recall that God hates lying lips.
Listen to the answer.
Listen to a friend who thinks differently.
Make the beginning exciting.
Write a catchy headline for a class event.
Explain the job of the first sentence (The Lead).
Match headlines to stories.
Explain the ethics of 'Clickbait' headlines.
Defend the importance of the lead in framing the reader's perspective.
Summarize the difference between Fact and Opinion.
Explain what it means to be 'fair' to both sides.
Explain the goal of neutrality in journalism.
Defend the Christian commitment to truth-telling over agenda-pushing.
Ask 'Who is it about?'.
Ask 'What happened?'.
Ask 'Where did it happen?'.
Draw a picture answering these questions.
Write a sentence including Who, What, When, and Where.
Explain why 'Why' and 'How' are sometimes harder to answer.
Check a story to see if any Ws are missing.
Interview a friend using the 5 Ws.
Explain how the 'How' adds context to the event.
Defend the necessity of factual completeness.
Tell the 'big news' first.
Summarize the concept of putting the most important facts at the top.
Explain why readers might stop reading after the first paragraph.
Explain the trade-off between brevity and detail.
Defend the utility of this structure for modern digital consumption.
Summarize the damage caused by rumors.
Explain the difference between reporting news and spreading gossip.
Explain the harm of 'Sensationalism'.
Defend the reputation of others as a form of love.
Check if the story is right.
Summarize why facts must be checked.
Explain what happens when newspapers make mistakes (Corrections).
Explain the pressure to be 'first' vs. being 'right'.
Defend the pursuit of objective truth in a post-truth culture.
Tell a true story like a storybook.
Describe what the person looks like.
Share how the person felt.
Use descriptive language (show, don't just tell).
Explain the setting of the true story.
Explain the concept of 'Creative Nonfiction' (true but artistic).
Defend the use of literary devices in journalism.
Draw a picture of a community helper.
Write three things about what they do.
Ask them why they like their job.
Share their story with the class.
Write a biography sketch of a family member.
Explain why this person is interesting.
Capture a specific moment in their life.
Describe their personality, not just their looks.
Explain the 'Nut Graf' (why we are reading this now).
Defend the dignity of the subject (Imago Dei) in the writing.
Look at the person talking.
Wait until they finish to speak.
Draw what they said.
Repeat what they said to check.
Write down key words while listening.
Summarize the main point of the speaker.
Use a recording device (with permission) to help remember.
Explain the importance of accuracy in quotes.
Defend the integrity of the subject's intent when editing quotes.
Think of a question to ask a friend.
Ask 'What is your favorite...?'
Take turns asking and answering.
Write down three questions before an interview.
Distinguish between 'Yes/No' questions and 'Tell me about' questions.
Explain why preparation helps you learn more.
Ask a follow-up question ('Why?').
Explain the strategy of ordering questions (easy to hard).
Defend the ethical boundaries of questioning (privacy vs. public interest).
Use speech bubbles for words spoken.
Say 'He said...' or 'She said...'.
Tell the truth about what someone said.
Don't change their words.
Use quotation marks around exact words.
Explain why we give credit to the speaker.
Attribute the quote to the correct person.
Explain the Eighth Commandment (Stealing) in relation to plagiarism/misquoting.
Defend the reputation of the subject by quoting fairly.
Sign your name to your work.
Say true things.
Don't say mean things.
Use a polite voice.
Understand that words have power.
Explain why newspapers have an 'Opinion' section.
Explain the responsibility of the 'Fourth Estate' (Press).
Defend the freedom of the press and speech.
State what you like or don't like.
Give a reason using 'because'.
Be kind when disagreeing.
Suggest a solution to the problem.
Explain why your solution is good.
Respect that others might have different ideas.
Explain the difference between an attack and an argument.
Defend a position with grace and truth (Colossians 4:6).
Compare a boring start with an interesting start.
Analyze different types of leads (Summary, Anecdotal, Question).
Interpret the tone of a headline (Sensational vs. Factual).
Connect the headline to the main idea of the article.
Compare a news report with an advertisement.
Analyze how word choice influences the reader's opinion (Framing).
Interpret the concept of 'Bias' in reporting.
Connect the worldview of the reporter to the angle of the story.
Analyze a lead paragraph to locate all 5 Ws.
Interpret the 'Why' to understand the significance of the event.
Connect the accuracy of the 5 Ws to the truthfulness of the report.
Compare a mystery story (climax at end) with a news story (climax at start).
Apply the Inverted Pyramid to organize a school report.
Analyze a newspaper article to identify the cutoff point for details.
Interpret the function of the 'Lead' paragraph.
Connect the structure to the history of the telegraph (conciseness).
Compare private information with public information.
Apply the 'THINK' test (True, Helpful, Inspiring, Necessary, Kind).
Analyze the legal concepts of Libel (written) and Slander (spoken).
Interpret the biblical warnings against the tongue (James 3).
Connect privacy rights to ethical reporting.
Compare a rumor with a verified fact.
Apply the Ninth Commandment (False Witness) to writing.
Analyze the consequences of 'Fake News'.
Interpret the concept of verification (two sources).
Connect accuracy to trust.
Compare a news report (facts) with a feature story (feelings/details).
Analyze the use of dialogue to bring scenes to life.
Interpret the narrative arc of a real-life event.
Connect the individual's story to a larger theme.
Analyze what makes a person 'newsworthy'.
Interpret the subject's words to find their motivation.
Connect the person's work to the community's needs.
Analyze the difference between verbatim quotes and paraphrasing.
Interpret body language and tone during an interview.
Connect active listening to building rapport.
Analyze the difference between Open-Ended and Closed-Ended questions.
Interpret the silence (waiting for the person to say more).
Connect the questions to the goal of the article.
Compare a direct quote with a summary.
Analyze when to use a full quote vs. a partial quote.
Interpret the use of ellipses (...) and brackets [ ].
Connect the credibility of the article to the quality of the sources.
Compare a reporter (neutral) with a columnist (opinionated).
Apply the Golden Rule to writing about others.
Analyze the influence of media on public opinion.
Interpret the tone of a piece (sarcastic, serious, hopeful).
Connect the writer's reputation to their credibility.
Analyze the structure of an Op-Ed (Opinion-Editorial).
Interpret the opposing viewpoint fairly.
Connect the issue to a moral principle.
Evaluate the impact of active verbs in headlines.
Evaluate the inevitability of bias and how to mitigate it.
Evaluate a report for gaps in information.
Evaluate the editorial decision-making process in cutting stories.
Evaluate the morality of paparazzi and invasion of privacy.
Evaluate the ethical failure of fabrication (e.g., Stephen Glass).
Evaluate the pacing of a long-form feature.
Evaluate the balance between praise and honest critique.
Evaluate the speaker's reliability or bias during the interview.
Evaluate the effectiveness of probing questions.
Evaluate the context of a quote to prevent misrepresentation.
Evaluate the ethical implications of advocating for a policy.
Evaluate the logical strength of your own position.
Create a short name for a picture.
Construct headlines that are both engaging and accurate.
Synthesize the article's content into a sub-head or deck.
Construct a report on a controversial topic using neutral language.
Synthesize conflicting reports to find the objective reality.
Construct a comprehensive lead that integrates all elements smoothly.
Synthesize multiple sources to answer the 'Why' comprehensively.
Construct a news article adhering strictly to the Inverted Pyramid.
Synthesize complex events into a prioritized narrative.
Construct an argument for ethical boundaries in reporting.
Synthesize legal constraints with moral obligations.
Construct a fact-checking protocol.
Synthesize the Christian duty to testify to the truth.
Construct a profile piece using immersion journalism techniques.
Synthesize facts and atmosphere to create empathy.
Construct a psychological profile based on interview and observation.
Synthesize the person's past, present, and future into a cohesive narrative.
Construct a transcript of a recorded interview.
Synthesize interview notes into a coherent narrative.
Construct a cohesive interview protocol for a subject matter expert.
Synthesize background research into intelligent inquiry.
Construct a balanced article using multiple sources.
Synthesize attribution verbs (said, claimed, argued) for precision.
Construct a unique authorial voice.
Synthesize personal conviction with public good.
Construct a persuasive editorial on a current event.
Synthesize facts and values to persuade a skeptical audience.
